title: Prognostic Scores: Disease-Specific Tools
summary: Comprehensive guide to disease-specific prognostic scoring systems across hematologic and solid tumor malignancies, including clinical applications and molecular integration.
author: OncoVISTA Team

content.text: Anatomical staging systems (e.g., TNM, Ann Arbor) are foundational, but insufficient for guiding personalized oncology care in the modern era. Disease-specific prognostic models integrate:

items: Tumor biology (e.g., genetic mutations, gene expression)
Host characteristics (age, comorbidities, immune status)
Functional measures (e.g., performance status, organ function)
Dynamic treatment response indicators (e.g., MRD, PET response)
Predict overall and progression-free survival
Estimate recurrence and transformation risk
Inform intensity, modality, and sequencing of therapy
Support clinical trial stratification and endpoints
Guide follow-up and surveillance regimens

content.text: The growing use of genomic assays, AI-assisted analytics, and liquid biopsy platforms has further sharpened the prognostic landscape.

items: IPI/NCCN-IPI: Combines age, stage, LDH, ECOG, and extranodal sites.
NCCN-IPI modifies IPI by refining age categories and assigning more weight to LDH elevation.
FLIPI/FLIPI-2: Predicts OS using clinical factors.
m7-FLIPI: Integrates 7 recurrent gene mutations (e.g., EZH2, TP53) with FLIPI and ECOG.
R-ISS / R2-ISS: Combines β2M, albumin, LDH, cytogenetics.
MRD (flow or NGS): Emerging standard for prognosis and therapy tailoring.
IPSS-R: Refined cytogenetics + continuous blood count metrics.
IPSS-M: Adds 31-gene NGS panel; improves AML prediction.
ELN 2022: Classifies AML into favorable, intermediate, and adverse-risk groups using cytogenetics and mutations (e.g., NPM1, FLT3-ITD, TP53).
Measurable Residual Disease (MRD): Central to transplant timing and intensification.
Sokal, Hasford, EUTOS, ELTS: Early tools to predict progression; ELTS now preferred in TKI era due to better OS correlation.
IPS (International Prognostic Score): For advanced-stage disease; based on 7 clinical factors.
A-HIPI: A more modern alternative reflecting better treatment outcomes.

rows: Guides chemo in ER+/HER2– node-negative (and selected node+) cases
Stratifies recurrence risk; TAILORx and MINDACT validated
Determines intrinsic subtype (e.g., Luminal A/B, HER2-E, Basal-like)

items: TAILORx: Up to 85% of postmenopausal women with intermediate RS (11–25) safely avoid chemo.
Oncotype DX RS ≥26: Recommend chemo in premenopausal patients.

rows: Histological risk; GG 1–5 aligns with long-term recurrence risk.
Combines PSA, Gleason, T-stage, % positive biopsies, age.
Predicts metastasis and mortality post-surgery or RT.
Groups based on PSA, Gleason, T-stage, and imaging.

content.text: High Decipher score (>0.6) → recommend adjuvant therapy even with negative margins.

rows: MSI-H tumors: favorable prognosis, poor 5-FU benefit, great ICI response
Validated in stage II for recurrence risk
T-cell density at tumor center/margin; enhances TNM accuracy

content.text: BRAF V600E mutation: Poor prognosis, worse ICI response in MSS tumors.

rows: Targeted therapy; survival depends on mutation subtype
Predicts response to immune checkpoint inhibitors
Correlates with local aggressiveness, relapse risk
Estimate recurrence risk, guide adjuvant therapy

content.text: In early-stage NSCLC, Adjuvant Osimertinib (ADAURA) is standard in resected EGFR-mutant cases.

rows: Time from diagnosis, Ca, Hgb, PLTs, ANC, ECOG
Historical; similar factors in VEGF-TKI context
Recurrence post-nephrectomy based on pathologic criteria
Strong adverse feature; poor ICI response

content.text: IMDC score drives first-line therapy selection: e.g., nivolumab + ipilimumab in poor risk.

rows: Recurrence risk; elevated in vascular invasion
Correlates with microvascular invasion, tumor grade

content.text: POLEmut tumors have excellent prognosis despite high-grade histology.

rows: IELSG Score (age, ECOG, LDH, CSF protein, sites)

content.text: MGMT methylation predicts temozolomide sensitivity in GBM.

rows: Day 29 MRD, cytogenetics (e.g., t(12;21), Ph+), CNS status

content.text: High-risk neuroblastoma with MYCN amplification → multimodal therapy + transplant.
Disease-specific prognostic tools form the cornerstone of risk-adapted oncology. Their utility is rapidly evolving from static classifiers to dynamic, multi-omic frameworks that combine:

items: Genomic profiling (DNA/RNA)
Real-time functional biomarkers (e.g., PET, MRD)
Patient-specific data (age, frailty, comorbidities)
AI-driven predictive models

content.text: As oncology enters an era of precision prognostication, these tools enable:

items: Personalized treatment planning
Informed patient counseling
More efficient clinical trial design
Improved survival with less toxicity

content.text: The next frontier involves adaptive scoring models that continuously update during therapy, reflecting tumor evolution and real-time treatment response.

items: Select disease-specific tools based on tumor type and available resources
Prioritize molecular testing when it impacts treatment decisions
Reassess prognostic risk at key clinical milestones (diagnosis, progression, post-treatment)
Combine static prognostic models with dynamic biomarkers (e.g., MRD, PET response)
Document prognostic scores in patient records to support clinical trial eligibility
